summary:
I am a Dutch artist, researcher and educator. My practice is situated in the field of ecological art and ecocriticism, with a specific interest in the topic of the influence of the technosphere on evolutionary processes and methods of attunement, particularly to matter and its situated and networked lives. My artistic practice is research-driven and finds its voice in developing and exhibiting artwork, writing, curating and developing education. For the past 4,5 years I have pioneered ecological art in the field of education, by founding and developing a new master's program “Ecology Futures” at the Master Institute of Visual Cultures of Avans University of Applied Sciences, that puts the exploration and invention of artistic-scientific methods at the forefront of practicing ecocritical theory in the field, aiming to find new ways of (co)generating practice-led knowledge in the process. Ecology Futures is the first MA program about ecological art in the Netherlands, as well as the first MA art program in the Netherlands to center, facilitate and teach biotechnological methodologies in an interdisciplinary setting. The latter was developed from my position as a researcher in the affiliated Biobased Art&Design Research group (CARADT) and in the newly installed Material Incubator Lab & Project Space, both led by Dr. Elvin Karana. 

I am at my best when spearheading innovation, and get my energy from bringing together transdisciplinary teams and developing programs that may bring well-informed, surprising, and layered ecocritical narratives. Over the years I’ve been involved with numerous institutions and initiatives, often leading to longstanding collaborations and multiple roles, such as with Common Ground (residency program curator followed by a public artwork commission), with FIBER Festival (residency/lab program curator, participating artist, education partner), with renowned design collective Dutch Invertuals (member and co-founder of Dutch Invertuals Academy), and with RAUM (co-curator/artistic advisor and curatorial manager of commissions). In my early career, I ran an agency for ecocritical designers, coaching and helping them develop their vision and business.

school.name: Royal Academy of Art, The Hague | Koninklijke Academie van Beeldende Kunsten (KABK)

certifications.name: OPEN SET Dutch Design Summer School 2016

projects.title: Ghost Reef
projects.description:
The many artificial substrates in the North Sea are biodiversity hotspots, cold water artificial reefs that surely play an immense role in the bigger ecosystem of this continental shelf — however, they are barely researched nor protected. The many patches of reefs are temporal, ephemeral, and alien, offer a sense of hope, and demonstrate resilience.
With Ghost Reef, Xandra van der Eijk attempts to plant the fantasy of a North Sea reef in the imagination. Animated video collages with 3D generated models based on the scarce footage taken by divers are juxtaposed with fieldrecording soundscapes taken at two locations: an oyster bank near the Brouwersdam in Zeeland, and the wreck of the Ara, a steamship that was sunk by a mine in 1942, located north of Schiermonnikoog.

With thousands of ship- and plane wrecks covering the North Sea floor, and thousands of other structures such as oil- and gas platforms and windmills serving as substrates, new underwater communities are continiously forming. Each community can exist due to its particular place in the sea and the conditions it is subjected to. In the vastness of murky water, colonized by humans, territories are lost, won, and expanded on. The structures themselves are time capsules that describe the process of colonization through its historical shipwrecks, its lost ammunition, its fishing gear, abandoned wells, and drilling platforms. Yet unseen to the human eye life unfolds. The anthropogenic structures are reclaimed by countless species; big and small. Each community is an ecosystem unique in its composition and has its own identity.

Ghost Reef was comissioned by Embassy of the North Sea
& MU Hybrid Art House.

Project partners
WMR, NIOZ, Dutch Maritime Productions
& Stichting Duik de Noordzee Schoon

3D modeling
Sacha van den Haak

Sound design
Sébastien Robert

projects.title: Retreat
projects.description:
As the impact of accelerating climate change is slowly revealing itself, we are confronted with how deeply our cultural identity is intertwined with the landscape. Imminent drastic alterations to the way we live cause profound feelings of unease, sadness, and detachment. Losing land to sea, losing ice to the sun, losing animals to history — how do we deal with this new notion of ecological grief?

RETREAT is a research into finding new ritualistic ways to preserve the landscape, offering actions, methods, and artifacts that help us deal with the emotions resulting from the changes in our environment as the result of global warming.

This project was originally developed in response to the theme TAKE AWAY by Dutch Invertuals, and was presented during Dutch Design Week 2018.

projects.title: Future Remnants
projects.description:
Future Remnants is a research into the influence of man on the evolutionary development of mineral formation. Based on scientific research that the surge in mineral diversity over the past fifty years can be attributed to man, the series of experiments can be seen as an advance on what is to come. Man is responsible for a large scale redistribution of matter, creating situations that lead to unintended and unexpected reactions. Using only widely available metals and solutions, applied in everyday life, the project demonstrates how credible the alteration of earth’s geology by mankind is while raising the question on what will emerge from our actions in deep time.

Future Remnants was developed as a response to the theme Mutant Matter by Dutch Invertuals in collaboration with Franklin Till, and was presented during Milan Design Week 2018.

projects.title: Estuary
projects.description:
Estuary forces saline and fresh water fluids together in a closed system. As salt-water organisms within battle decay due to their hostile environment, plentiful fresh-water life springs from its forced death. What’s visible is the colorful behavior of living organisms struggling to manage a situation orchestrated by human hands.

Estuaries are transition zones between fresh water and salt-water environments. They are areas of exchange, usually rich in nutrients and providing conditions for sea life to flourish. This potential abundance is overshadowed however, as more than half of the human population concentrates near estuaries. The anthropogenic influence on their biology is significant, and is inspiration for the tensions demonstrated in this work.

projects.title: Genesis [Research]
projects.description:
Within the ongoing research project Genesis, I am studying the color properties of extremophiles, microbes that can survive or even thrive under extreme conditions. These life forms can be traced back millions of years, and are speculated to be the earliest forms of life on the planet. Their robustness and stability, even in environments as unforgiving as space, suggest they are likely the first sort of extraterrestrial life we expect to one day discover.

By sampling fluids from volcanic hot springs and high saline ponds during research trips to Iceland and France, I managed to isolate several strains that produce pigments. At the moment, I am conducting the next step in my research: attempting to master and influence the pigment production, eventually hoping to induce a full color change in the microbes. With Genesis, I am hacking the origin of life, ultimately questioning who is in control.

projects.title: Colors of the Oosterschelde
projects.description: A research into the dye proporties of seaweed and algae in textiles. In the Oosterschelde area, a Dutch coastal zone sheltered from the Northsea by a storm surge barrier, I collected more than twenty different species of seaweed to experiment with. This resulted in over 400 samples of colored fabric and yarn. This project was made possible by the Creative Industries Fund NL.

projects.title: Momentum
projects.description: Momentum shows the process of transience and the human incapability to overcome it. In a four meter wide container an algae enriched base is the stage for pigments to perform. Slowly, drops fall from glass pipes, onto the surface, pushing one another away as they touch. The result is an ever changing drawing, striking much resemblance with growth rings or sedimentation. By placing the glass pipes in a subsequent position, the once beautiful drawing is gently forced aside for a new one, thus creating an every changing timeline.

profile_positions.description:
Artistic research 
www.xandravandereijk.nl

My practice is situated in the field of ecological art and ecocriticism, with a specific interest in the topic of the influence of the technosphere on evolutionary processes and the act of attunement, particularly to matter and its situated and networked lives. My research is voiced by developing and exhibiting artwork, writing, curating, and developing education. Over the years I have come to use a distinct artistic methodology combining theory, fieldwork, documentation methods, and material experimentation, bringing forth new ecocritical narratives. My work has been nominated and awarded multiple times and is exhibited throughout the world.
profile_positions.title: Independent Artist

profile_positions.company: University of Applied Sciences and Arts Northwestern Switzerland FHNW
profile_positions.description:
https://criticalmedialab.ch/

Co-manager reading group "Planetary Ecologies" and associated researcher in the Cycles of Circulation project. Cycles of Circulation creates new ways of relating to and representing ecologies, and interventions in climate governance processes through creative and scholarly practices. The project examines historical as well as contemporary and speculative relationships at the intersection of political ecology, science and technology studies, and art, design and media as knowledge practices. It is interested in contemplating the entangled metabolisms of organisms and their environments, and instances in which ‘cycles’ are used and abused in ecological, technological and political histories and communications, and in the ramifications of these in public imaginaries.
profile_positions.title: Associated Researcher, Critical Media Lab

profile_positions.description:
www.akvstjoostmasters.nl

Van der Eijk is Course Leader at the Masters Institute of Visual Cultures for the new research pathway Ecology Futures. Her role is to develop the curriculum, build the team and find the right collaboration partners. She hopes to translate her deep interest in human-made ecosystems and the rich knowledge on biobased materials present in the institute and in her own practice, into a critical MA course that brings forth artists that know how to imagine, shape and comment on alternative ecological futures.
profile_positions.title: Course Leader, MA Ecology Futures

profile_positions.description:
https://caradt.com/

Researcher at the Centre of Applied Research for Art, Design and Technology as part of the Biobased Art & Design research group led by Dr. Elvin Karana.
profile_positions.title: Researcher, Biobased Art & Design, CARADT

profile_positions.description: A shared position between the Faculty of Arts and the Faculty of Environmental Sciences, the topic of this PhD focussed on art engaging the geographical context. Through both theoretical and practice-led research, I hoped to find out how experimental art can play a role in the engagement with, and communication of, the evidence and impacts of environmental change.
profile_positions.title: PhD Researcher

profile_positions.description:
www.raumutrecht.nl 

Being involved with RAUM from the start, my role is to advise and reflect on the artistic programme. Together with fellow team members Danielle Arets and Joop de Boer, I am responsible for selecting and inviting artists and designers for the artist-in-residence programme. In addition, I am closely involved in the realization of the selected projects, guiding and reflecting on the artistic process to achieve the best possible result from the installations we commission. 

About RAUM
—
RAUM is creating an open cross-disciplinary cultural space at Berlijnplein in Utrecht, where local, national and international makers can team up with the public to create ground-breaking experiences. On the intersecting plane of art, design and technology, we wish to work with makers to create a continuous programme of public installations and to organize meaningful festivals and workshops. Everyone is welcome at RAUM to propose and carry out creative ideas, with innovative forms and connections as a result. RAUM can never be ‘finished’, but continues to respond to changes and events in its environment. That is how RAUM will shape and nurture a new cultural heart in Utrecht.
profile_positions.title: Co-curator + Commission Consultant

profile_positions.description:
www.openset.nl

Having followed the Summer School Programme of Open Set in 2016, through a joint scholarship of Creative Industries Fund NL and Open Set, I joined the alumni board of the foundation in 2017, to advise and reflect on the development of the curriculum and programme structure. 

—
Open Set is an independent education platform that promotes the social relevance of design and visual culture. Our organization began as a Dutch Design summer school in 2012 and has grown to include a broad spectrum of year-round activities.

In a world of accelerated change where the future is increasingly uncertain, Open Set advocates for the growing critical role of design and visual culture. However, we reject the current view of design as a panacea for global challenges1. Our ambition is to re-complicate design’s engagement with contemporary problems by opening up the conversation between different schools of thought, disciplines, and cultures.
If we are to re-define the roles and terms of design, we need environments that structurally facilitate experimentation and the ‘unlearning’ of professional conventions and expectations. The seed of this transformation in design thinking is the ethical position of an individual designer, situated in and committed to a specific time and place.
profile_positions.title: Advisory Board Member

profile_positions.description:
www.dutchdesignfoundation.com

For the edition of Dutch Design Week in 2018, themed 'If Not Us, Then Who?', I developed multiple pilot programmes in collaboration with the DDF team, such as a programme with themed routes and talks, and an exclusive tour programme about art & collectible design. In addition, I was closely involved in this year's single edition of Good Design For A Bad World, a collaboration between DDF and Dezeen in which today's pressing issues are discussed with leading experts from the design world and beyond. The topic of the 2018 discussion was the Anthropocene. 

About Dutch Design Foundation
—
We believe that 'designers' - no matter their specialization - are essential for shaping our future. Which is why Dutch Design Foundation focuses on the strengthening of their position, their development and their importance. We do this by supporting Dutch designers, deploy the power of innovative and visionary design on an even greater scale, stimulating excellence through supporting talent, exploration of the current meaning of Dutch Design and offering inspiration; providing direction, facilitating research and debate.
profile_positions.title: Freelance Programmer

profile_positions.description:
www.iwaithere.com

For 6 years, I did everything in my power to aid young designers and artists in advancing their career. Starting with advising, writing grant proposals and developing prototypes to products, right up to developing a platform to promote and sell their work. Through time, I developed a coaching structure of multiple sessions, in which my clients were challenged to decide upon their core business and structure their practices in service of their unique identity. The sessions were focussed on strategy, finance, marketing, communication, and sales - the latter in the broadest sense of the word. Being an artist or designer, finding a way to earn a living off your work is not easy. It demands a creative approach to business, and that is exactly what I invited my clients to work on. 

Amongst my longer-term clients were Kirstie van Noort, Alissa+Nienke, Aliki van der Kruijs and Studio Roos Meerman. Shorter-term clients include Handmade Industrials and Jetske Visser & Michiel Martens. 

—
I Wait Here highly values research-based, conceptual projects and products from emerging designers and artists working on the intersection of art, science and technology. By providing individual project support we create space for the designers and artists to make new work. I Wait Here primarily offers professional artistic coaching, business support, PR and project management. Day to day activities include writing grant proposals, analysing artistic work and advise on business choices. We aim to support our clients for a long time and by doing so, hope to make a valuable contribution to both their career and the field of design and art in general.
profile_positions.title: Founder + Art/Design Consultant
